newsitem.title: USA: Calif. Assembly panel OKs bond district aid bill.
newsitem.headline: Calif. Assembly panel OKs bond district aid bill.

text.p: A California legislative committee has approved a bill to aid financially troubled bond districts, state officials said on Thursday.
The state Assembly Committee on Local Government approved Assembly Bill 1224 on a vote of 13-to-0. The bill now advances to the judiciary committee, which is likely to consider the measure next week.

The bill would create a series of mechanisms to deal with financially failing Mello-Roos bond districts. At least $87 million of outstanding Mello-Roos bonds have experienced delinquencies in California, bond analysts said.
Mello-Roos bonds are issued under the California's Mello-Roos Community Facilities Act of 1982.
The act allows local agencies to form community facilities districts that can issue bonds and levy special taxes to finance projects and services.
More than 125 Mello-Roos districts statewide have issued close to $3 billion of bonds since the act went into effect.

* Require the establishment of a sinking fund when bonds are issued. The district would notify the California Debt and Investment Advisory Commission within 10 days of any failure to make the required payments to the sinking fund.
* Allow the district to waive certain delinquency penalties.
* Allow property owners to pay off taxes owed to districts with bonds or other debt obligations.

* Provide a tax penalty amnesty program if tax delinquencies exceed 10 percent of the total tax levy for two years running, or if at least one foreclosure sale occurred with no minimum bids being accepted.
* Make it easier for districts to foreclose on delinquent properties.
